div.p: Viennese dealer in sheet music and other services.

div.head: Career Summary
div.p: Alexander Rosé was the son of Herman and Maria Rosé, and elder brother of cellist Eduard Rosé, and violinist Arnold Rosé, and Berthold Rosé. Unlike his brothers, Alexander entered commerce, the proprietor of three Vienna businesses: Art and sheet music retailer, Sheet music hire service, and Concert agency, all at Vienna I, Kärntnerring, 11. In 1907, he replaced the hire service with an antiquarian business (not specified as music).
His personal entry in Lehmann’s Vienna Directory for 1903 reads: Rosé Alexander, I. Kärnthnerring 8, Kunst- u. Musikalienhdl., Musikalien-Leih-Anst. u. conc. Concert-Bur., I. Kärnthnerring 11.

Judging from his entries in Lehmann, Rosé set up business as the art and sheet music retailer in 1892, adding the hire service the following year, and the concert agency in 1897. These businesses were at their full extent between 1893 and 1914. After that date, the concert agency was dropped in 1915, in which year his premises moved from Kärntnerring 11 to Kolowratring 9, the antiquarian business in 1923, by which year the proprietorship had been acquired by Ludwig Kern.

div.head: Alexander Rosé and Schenker
div.p: No correspondence between the two men is known to survive. In a letter to Ferruccio Busoni (Sbb B II 4428, January 3, 1899), in what looks like an attempt on Schenker’s part to woo Busoni from concert agent Albert J. Gutmann over to Rosé for his Vienna concerts, Schenker remarks: “Privately, I am very good friends with Mr. Rosé.”
